Homer Glen girl goes off to spring training Peyton Kirk Courtesy of Advocate Children's Hospital 
Peyton Kirk, of Homer Glen, waits to board a plane at O'Hare Airport Tuesday afternoon to take her and eight other young patients from Advocate Children's Hospital to Cubs training camp in Mesa, Ariz. 
Peyton Kirk, of Homer Glen, waits to board a plane at O'Hare Airport Tuesday afternoon to take her and eight other young patients from Advocate Children's Hospital to Cubs training camp in Mesa, Ariz. (Courtesy of Advocate Children's Hospital) Susan DeMar Lafferty baseball hat, and later snapped a photo of her wearing it when she was less than one day old.
This week, 10 years and five heart procedures later, the young lady from Homer Glen, who was born into a family of Cubs fans, joined eight other children — all current and former patients from Advocate Children's Hospitals in Oak Lawn and Park Ridge — on the Kids, Cubs and Cactus Road Trip. The event is an all expenses paid trip to Cubs' spring training camp in Mesa, Ariz. 
The trip was made possible through a partnership with Advocate Children's Hospital, the Cubs organization and American Airlines, which covered the air fare for each child and two others in their family. 
The children were nominated and selected by child life specialists at Advocate, who were seeking kids who had "been through a lot" and were, of course, Cubs fans, said Cristina Enea, Advocate's marketing coordinator. 
"We have nine kids — all have different personalities, all have different ailments, but the one thing they have in common is that they are all Cubs fans," she said. 
Advocate Health does events with the Cubs organization throughout the year, including trips to Wrigley Field, but this year, they were able to step up their game, she said. 
"We try to go above and beyond," she said of this first time trip to spring training. "It's really cool to give these kids an opportunity they would not normally get." 
Some are going through treatment but still able to travel, she said. Advocate Children's Hospital visit to Cubs spring training Courtesy of Advocate Children's Hospital 
Kids wait to meet Cubs players at Sloan Park in Mesa, Ariz. Wednesday. Photo courtesy of Advocate Children's Hospital. 
Kids wait to meet Cubs players at Sloan Park in Mesa, Ariz. Wednesday. Photo courtesy of Advocate Children's Hospital. (Courtesy of Advocate Children's Hospital) 
Peyton was born with a congenital heart defect, and has undergone two open heart surgeries — the first when she was 10 months old — and three related procedures, said her mother, Monica Kirk. 
Peyton just had her pacemaker replaced two weeks ago, and will need one the rest of her life, she said. 
"So many of these kids have medical issues, but this gives them something to look forward to," she said. 
For Peyton, the trip not only means a break from school, but from physical therapy and doctor appointments, her mother said. 
"This gives her a chance to be a kid," she said. The Kirk family had been to Cubs' games, but never to spring training. 
"It's truly unbelievable," said Peyton's brother Zach, 18, who accompanied his sister and mother on the trip. "It's really humbling for everyone who gets to go." 
Peyton was "excited" to be selected, and kept asking, "is this real life?" her mother said. Advocate Children's Hospital visit to Cubs spring training Courtesy of Advocate Children's Hospital 
Nine current and former patients of Advocate Children's Hospital were given an all expenses paid trip to Cubs spring training in Mesa, Ariz., this week. 
Nine current and former patients of Advocate Children's Hospital were given an all expenses paid trip to Cubs spring training in Mesa, Ariz., this week. (Courtesy of Advocate Children's Hospital) 
The group of 35, which included the nine patients, ages 8 to 14 years, their families, and a medical team, left O'Hare Airport in early Tuesday afternoon and were scheduled to arrive in Arizona at 4:30 p.m. for dinner. 
Wednesday's busy schedule included breakfast at Sloan Park in Mesa, Arizona, and a tour of the spring training facilities, followed by activities, games, and meeting Cubs players. 
Ball players were aware the kids were coming and looked forward to it, Enea said. 
The group was scheduled to return to Chicago by 9 p.m. Wednesday.
